conversations.content: A Friend Eternal: Part One
Once there was a count's daughter whose lands were beset by fiends, causing her to lose family and home. Finally, she fled to a nearby territory ruled by a friend of her father.
She walked for days upon end, until darkness and exhaustion threatened to claim her. But just then, she saw an old empty castle in the distance, and was able to slip through its gate.
As she entered the empty great hall, a chill ran down her spine—for it was lined with taxidermied humans! Then, five words echoed out in the hall: ＂Do you like my friends?＂
The inhuman voice terrified the girl, but she found the strength to reply. ＂I needed a shelter from the night,＂ she said. ＂Pray forgive my intrusion.＂
＂Eee hee hee!＂ laughed the voice. ＂I am not mad at you, dear girl. In fact, I was just wishing I had one such as you I could call my friend.＂
＂For it is dark in here, and ever so lonely—but I would not be lonely if I had more friends. Will you not remain and be my friend eternal?＂
＂I would be happy to be your friend,＂ responded the girl in a trembling voice. ＂But not like the others who you named friend—I will not spend eternity as such a horror.＂
＂And yet your life is short,＂ replied the voice. ＂I will have you as a friend for only fifty years or so, which will pass in a moment. Would you not prefer to live forever as my other friends do?＂
＂I have seen your other friends,＂ said the girl, ＂and I know they cannot speak, being stuffed as they are. How boring that must be for you!＂
＂And yet, an eternity of silence is better than the pain of your loss.＂ These words chilled the girl to her bone, for they gave her a sense of how lonely immortality truly was.
And while she was not immortal, the girl also knew the pain of loss— for just recently had everything she knew and loved been torn from her.
She had set out to right that wrong; to find a way to dispel her newfound loneliness and start a family anew— which was why she could not afford to spend eternity as a mannequin.
And so the young girl steeled her spine and began the discussion that would determine her fate for all time...
A Friend Eternal: Part Two
Surrounded by stuffed humans, the girl looked on with fear at the mistress of the castle—who resembled nothing less than a little girl of roughly her own age.
Though the mistress looked at her with love, the girl knew she would be stuffed and mounted unless she was able to convince her otherwise, so she opened her mouth and said:
＂I know you want lots of friends, but if you make me into one of your dolls, I will be a poor friend to you.＂
＂Yet if you release me, I will have fifty years in which to start a family and have many children of my own.＂
＂If you let me go, I promise to tell my children about you. They will do the same for their children in turn, which ensures you will always have friends who remember you fondly.＂
＂Eee hee hee!＂ replied the mistress. ＂Then I will have friends everlasting!＂ Overjoyed, she released the girl the very next day.
Years later, the girl was married, and blessed with many fine children. The count's lineage, which had been so close to vanishing, now flourished.
She kept her promise to the mistress, telling each of her children the story of that fateful night in the castle—for she believed that was the source of all the good fortune in her life.
And yet, she could not fully rejoice, for while her many heirs brought her endless happiness, she was unable to forget the loneliness she felt in the voice of the mistress.
The girl grew old. Her children and grandchildren married. And one day, she left her home and went to the castle, never to return. Did it soothe her lonelieness? Alas, none can say.
